DOCNAME: CASE OF SHINDLER v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;No violation of Article 3 of Protocol No. 1 - Right to free elections-{general} (Article 3 of Protocol No. 1 - Vote)
JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;George Nicolaou;Ineta Ziemele;Ledi Bianku;Paul Mahoney;Vincent A. De Gaetano;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in ORG , GPE . He left GPE in DATE following his retirement and moved to GPE with his wife , an NORP national .

CARDINAL . Pursuant to primary legislation , NORP citizens residing overseas for DATE are permitted to vote in parliamentary elections in GPE ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) . The applicant does not meet the DATE criterion and is therefore not entitled to vote . In particular , he was unable to vote in the general election of CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the Representation of the People Act DATE ( “ the DATE LAW ) provides that a person is entitled to vote as an elector at a parliamentary election if on the date of the poll he is , inter alia , registered in the register of parliamentary electors for a constituency and is either a ORG citizen or a citizen of GPE . Pursuant to section PERSON ) , a person is entitled to be registered if on the relevant date he is , inter alia , resident in the constituency and is either a ORG citizen or a citizen of GPE .

CARDINAL . Sections DATE of the DATE Act allow certain categories of persons otherwise eligible to vote who do not fulfill the normal residence requirements to continue to register to vote by making a “ service declaration ” . A service declaration can be made by a person who is ( a ) a member of the forces , ( b ) employed in the service of the ORG in a post outside GPE of any prescribed class or description , ( c ) employed by ORG in a post outside GPE , or ( d ) the spouse or civil partner of a person falling within categories ( a ) , ( b ) or ( c ) above .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provides that where a person ’s service declaration is in force , he shall be regarded for the purposes of section CARDINAL of LAW as a resident on the date of the declaration at the address specified in it ( current or former address in GPE ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Representation of the People Act DATE as amended ( “ the DATE LAW ) provides that a person who is a NORP citizen is entitled to vote as an elector at a parliamentary election if he qualifies as an overseas elector on the date on which he makes an “ overseas elector ’s declaration ” ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . A person qualifies as an overseas elector if he is not resident in GPE and he satisfies one of the sets of conditions set out in the legislation .
CARDINAL . The relevant set of conditions for the purpose of the present case is set out in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) :
“ The first set of conditions is that—
( a ) he was included in a register of parliamentary electors in respect of an address at a place that is situated within the constituency concerned ,
( b ) that entry in the register was made on the basis that he was resident , or to be treated for the purposes of registration as resident , at that address ,

( c ) that entry in the register was in force at any time falling within the period of DATE immediately before the relevant date [ i.e. the date on which the applicant makes a declaration under section CARDINAL ] , and

( d ) subsequent to that entry ceasing to have effect no entry was made in any register of parliamentary electors on the basis that he was resident , or to be treated for the purposes of registration as resident , at any other address . ”

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that a person is entitled to be registered pursuant to an “ overseas elector ’s declaration ” in the constituency where he was last registered to vote or last resided and the registration officer concerned is satisfied that he qualifies as an overseas elector in respect of that constituency . Where the entitlement of a person to remain registered as an overseas voter terminates , the registration officer concerned shall remove that person ’s entry from the register ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) requires that an overseas elector ’s declaration state the date of the declaration , that the declarant is a NORP citizen , that the declarant is not resident in GPE , and the date on which he ceased to be so resident .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) stipulates that an overseas elector ’s declaration must show which set of conditions in section CARDINAL of the Act the declarant claims to satisfy and , in the case of the first set of conditions , specify the address in respect of which he was registered .

CARDINAL . Prior to the enactment of the DATE Act , no NORP citizen living overseas could vote in a parliamentary , i.e. general , election in GPE , other than members of the armed forces or ORG servants .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE a parliamentary committee , ORG , published a report on ORG which recommended that NORP citizens living in what were then Member GPE of ORG should be able to vote in parliamentary elections for an indefinite period . The Government ’s response to that report recommended a DATE limit for all overseas voters , expressing the view that a person ’s links with GPE were likely to have weakened significantly if he had lived outside it for DATE .

CARDINAL . The DATE Act as originally enacted extended the right to vote to NORP citizens resident overseas but who had been resident in GPE within DATE . The bill originally proposed a DATE period but concerns were expressed during the passage of the bill that that period was both too long and too short . Further concerns regarding the inability of a straightforward time - limit to reflect the positions and intentions of individuals regarding their contact with GPE were also raised .

CARDINAL . The DATE period was extended to DATE by virtue of section QUANTITY of the Representation of the People Act DATE . The bill which led to the LAW was prepared following consultation and proposed increasing the time - limit to DATE . During parliamentary debates , the Secretary of ORG acknowledged that there was no correct answer as to where the correct cut - off point lay and explained that a balance had to be struck between the interests of those who , although resident abroad for some time , had retained close and continuing connection with GPE and those who had “ cut adrift ” from such links much earlier . Parliamentarians expressed a broad spectrum of views , with some opposing any change which would allow those resident abroad for long periods to vote and others arguing that restrictions on the right to vote should be kept to a minimum .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the DATE Act was subsequently repealed and replaced , with retention of DATE , by section CARDINAL and Schedule CARDINAL of the Representation of LAW .

CARDINAL . In DATE the Home Affairs Select Committee published a report on ORG . It proposed that the period during which overseas voters be permitted to vote be reduced . The relevant extract of its report reads :

“ CARDINAL . The Representation of the People Act DATE introduced a right for NORP citizens resident overseas on the qualifying date to register as a voter for parliamentary and NORP elections for DATE following their move overseas . This period was increased to DATE under the Representation of the People Act DATE . The peak year for actual registrations under the LAW was in DATE when CARDINAL registered ; the numbers have steadily decreased since then until a rise in DATE , when the total stood at CARDINAL , followed by a further fall in DATE to CARDINAL . Estimates of the potential number who could register have ranged QUANTITY .

CARDINAL . It has been suggested that it is unreasonable for people who have been away for so long to retain the right to vote . Professor PERSON argued that the system meant that ‘ an expatriate living QUANTITY away , for the duration of a period exceeding a whole generation , carrying memories of NORP politics in the past and with little or no personal knowledge of contemporary issues in the constituency where he or she used to live , can influence the election of the government of a country to which he is not subject and to whom he or she may be paying no taxes’ . Electoral administrators pointed out that there were costs attached to registering overseas citizens and that a shorter period might be cheaper and easier to operate . ORG and GPE NORP representatives both suggested that DATE was perhaps too long . Professor PERSON suggested that the right to vote while overseas might be related in some way to the nature of the links retained with the GPE or to an intention to return .

CARDINAL . On the other hand , it is clear that the present rules – with so few persons actually registering – cause very little disruption or distortion to the actual results and , for ORG , PERSON indicated that changing the time limit was not a priority issue . It must also be likely that those who do register are those with the greater commitment to events in the GPE and are those most likely to be planning to return . A further restraining factor is that overseas voters have to vote by proxy ( because it is not possible to send a ballot paper overseas reliably in the time available ) which means that in order to exercise their right to vote they have to establish some form of connection with their former home . ORG reported that most of the correspondence they received on this issue was not from people calling for DATE period to be lowered but from people who had been resident overseas for DATE arguing for it to be increased .

CARDINAL . On balance , we take the view that DATE maximum period within which a NORP citizen overseas may retain the right to vote is excessive and that the earlier limit – DATE should be restored . ” ( emphasis in original ; references omitted )

CARDINAL . The DATE period was subsequently reduced to DATE pursuant to section CARDINAL(a ) of the Political Parties , LAW . The bill preceding the LAW proposed a reduction to DATE . CARDINAL . During a short debate in ORG on DATE regarding voting arrangements for overseas electors , some members called on the ORG to reconsider the DATE period . CARDINAL . On DATE , during the passage through ORG of the bill which led to ORG , an amendment was proposed in ORG to remove the DATE rule . The reasons for the proposed amendment were explained as follows :

“ According to ORG , CARDINAL NORP citizens currently live abroad . In most other countries , both developed and emerging , voting rights for parliamentary elections depend solely on nationality , not on an arbitrary time limit . CARDINAL . The Government minister responded that the question whether the time limit was appropriate was a wider question which remained under consideration within Government . He noted that there were valid arguments on both sides which needed to be carefully considered alongside any practical issues before any informed decisions could be taken . Again , the Government minister indicated that the issue was under consideration by Government and the amendment was withdrawn .

CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG handed down judgment in the case of GPE v ORG and Lord President of the ORG . The claimant was a long - term resident of GPE who sought judicial review of the DATE rule under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the DATE Act . He argued that he had a directly effective right under ORG law to move to and reside in other Member GPE and that the DATE rule operated unjustifiably to interfere with the exercise of that right .

CARDINAL . The court found that there was no evidential basis for the contention that the DATE rule created a barrier of any kind to free movement . The matter therefore did not fall within the scope of ORG law . That being so , the issue of justification did not arise . The court nonetheless indicated that it considered the rule to be a proportionate interference with the right to free movement . It was of the view that the Government were entitled to hold that there was a legitimate objective which the rule was designed to achieve , namely to remove the right to vote from those whose links with GPE had diminished and who were not , for the most part at least , directly affected by the laws passed there . It observed :

“ DATE . ... [ T]he DATE rule is designed to establish a test to identify when the absence of residence can fairly be said to have diluted the link with the GPE sufficient to justify the removal of the right to vote . The fact that some residence tests do not properly or proportionately measure the strength of commitment does not mean that the adoption of a non - residence test can not legitimately measure the weakening of commitment . This rule does not fix on non - residence at some particular point in time ; it requires a consistent period of non - residence . In my judgment that is a justified way to measure the dilution of commitment . Thereafter the choice of a bright line rule is inevitable . It would in my view be wholly impracticable to adopt a rule which required consideration of the personal circumstances of all potential expatriate voters ... ”

CARDINAL . The court found that decisions of this ORG upholding residence rules were “ highly material ” ( referring to GPE v. GPE ( dec . ) , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , ORG CARDINALVI ; PERSON v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , § CARDINAL , ECHR CARDINAL ; and PERSON GPE DATE . ) , no . CARDINAL , DATE ) .

CARDINAL . Finally , the court considered that the exceptions to the DATE period for certain categories of citizens were justified as the individuals concerned were resident in other GPE at the request of GPE in order to look after its national interests .

CARDINAL . In its judgment of DATE , ORG upheld the judgment of ORG on both the question of the existence of an interference with free movement rights and the question of justification . Lord Justice Mummery gave the judgment for the court and , on the latter issue , noted in particular :

“ CARDINAL . First , ORG was entitled to hold ... that the DATE rule had a legitimate aim , i.e. to test the strength of a NORP citizen ’s links with the GPE over a significant period of time by measuring past commitment to the GPE and seeing whether it was sufficiently diminished or diluted to justify removal of the right to vote in parliamentary elections . That aim was legitimate for the purpose of confining the parliamentary franchise to those citizens with an ascertainable , continuing , close and objective connection with the GPE , whose government made decisions and whose ORG passed laws that most directly affected those NORP citizens resident in the GPE .

CARDINAL . Secondly , the residence of a citizen is not ... an arbitrary measure of connection with a country : far from it , residence is a relevant , rational and practicable criterion for assessing the closeness of the links between a NORP citizen and the GPE .

CARDINAL . Thirdly , the DATE rule is proportionate to the aim . The length of the period represents CARDINAL NORP terms . It provides a substantial opportunity for continued voting by NORP citizens who have moved to reside in another ORG country .

CARDINAL . Fourthly , it is impracticable for the franchise criteria to be other than bright line rules capable of reasonably consistent practical application . It would be unworkable and disproportionate for the electoral authorities to have to make individual merits assessments of the particular circumstances of each resident in another ORG country on a case - by - case basis in order to determine how close a connection there is between that particular individual and the GPE despite prolonged absence .

CARDINAL . Fifthly , there is no objectionable inconsistency of treatment arising from the excepted categories of overseas residents , such as members of the armed services and ORG employees . In general , they do not move to reside overseas as a voluntary exercise of the right to free movement ... [ T]heir circumstances are distinguishable from those of the claimant and others who , like him , have chosen , for their own personal reasons , to live in another Member ORG . ”
